<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_bd_sync:
```c
static int lfs_bd_sync(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate) {
    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, rcache);

    int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, pcache, rcache, validate);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    err = lfs->cfg->sync(lfs->cfg);
    LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_bd_sync:
static inline void lfs_cache_drop(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_cache_t *rcache) {
    // do not zero, cheaper if cache is readonly or only going to be
    // written with identical data (during relocates)
    (void)lfs;
    rcache->block = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_flush(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate) {
    if (pcache->block != LFS_BLOCK_NULL && pcache->block != LFS_BLOCK_INLINE) {
        LFS_ASSERT(pcache->block < lfs->block_count);
        lfs_size_t diff = lfs_alignup(pcache->size, lfs->cfg->prog_size);
        int err = lfs->cfg->prog(lfs->cfg, pcache->block,
                pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
        LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        if (validate) {
            // check data on disk
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, rcache);
            int res = lfs_bd_cmp(lfs,
                    NULL, rcache, diff,
                    pcache->block, pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
            if (res < 0) {
                return res;
            }

            if (res != LFS_CMP_EQ) {
                return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
            }
        }

        lfs_cache_zero(lfs, pcache);
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static inline void lfs_cache_zero(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_cache_t *pcache) {
    // zero to avoid information leak
    memset(pcache->buffer, 0xff, lfs->cfg->cache_size);
    pcache->block = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_cmp(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, lfs_size_t hint,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    const uint8_t *data = buffer;
    lfs_size_t diff = 0;

    for (lfs_off_t i = 0; i < size; i += diff) {
        uint8_t dat[8];

        diff = lfs_min(size-i, sizeof(dat));
        int err = lfs_bd_read(lfs,
                pcache, rcache, hint-i,
                block, off+i, &dat, diff);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        int res = memcmp(dat, data + i, diff);
        if (res) {
            return res < 0 ? LFS_CMP_LT : LFS_CMP_GT;
        }
    }

    return LFS_CMP_EQ;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(pcache->buffer, 0xff, lfs->cfg->cache_size);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code: lfs_cache_zero calls memset(pcache->buffer, 0xff, lfs->cfg->cache_size). From the surrounding code and API design, pcache->buffer is intended to be a cache buffer allocated to lfs->cfg->cache_size, so the memset length matches the actual object size and does not access out-of-bounds. A possible violation scenario would be if pcache or lfs->cfg were misinitialized or corrupted (e.g. pcache->buffer points to a smaller allocation than lfs->cfg->cache_size), in which case the memset could overflow the buffer, but that is a separate initialization/invariant fault rather than misuse of memset here.
